newsitem.title: BELGIUM: SGB sees opportunities in ex-Zaire.
newsitem.headline: SGB sees opportunities in ex-Zaire.

text.p: Societe Generale de Belgique SA (SGB) said on Thursday it saw new business opportunities in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (formerly Zaire) following the rise to power of the rebel alliance headed by Laurent-Desire Kabila.

"We see opportunities in Congo. We have a tradition there. We have knowledge and people. We think we must proceed there cautiously... We only ask any (ventures) there can be set up under reasonable circumstances," SGB Chairman Etienne Davignon told the company's annual shareholders meeting.

SGB is Belgium's oldest holding company and has strong links with the country's former colony. SGB's 51 percent owned mining unit Union Miniere used to run the country's copper mines, before they were nationalised by Zaire's former leader Mobutu Sese Seko. UM's industrial diamond unit Sibeka still has a stake in the country's diamond mines.
SGB also has interests in the Congo's banking and other sectors through units Belgolaise and Finoutremer.
Davignon did not specify in which areas the group saw new business opportunities.
